The merits of the other natures will now be explained next. Among them, the concentrations that are the bases will be explained first.
What are the dhyÄnas among the various concentrations?
Verse:
The dhyÄnas are four each with two, the arising within them has been explained.
Concentration refers to wholesome one-pointedness, with its associates it has the nature of the five aggregates.
The first has initial thought, sustained thought, joy, and pleasure, the latter gradually eliminate the preceding factors.
The treatise says:
Since all merits mostly rely on dhyÄna, therefore one should first explain the distinctions of dhyÄna.
In total there are four kinds, namely the first, second, third, and fourth. Each of the four has two, namely concentration and arising.
The essence of the dhyÄna of arising has already been explained in the chapter on the worlds, namely the fourth has eight, and the first three each have three.
In general, the substance of samÄdhi is the concentration of good mind, because its nature is that of good samÄdhi.
If it is considered with its auxiliaries, it has the five aggregates as its substance.
What is meant by â€œthe concentration of mind on one object?â€
It means the concentration of mind on a single object.
If this is so, then the name samÄdhi is established on the basis of the state in which mind is concentrated on a single object, and there should be no other mental activities besides this.
There is a separate dharma that causes mind to be concentrated on a single object and is called samÄdhi. Its substance is not mind itself.
Is it not the case that all minds are concentrated on a single object because they perish from moment to moment? What use is there for samÄdhi?
If it is said that samÄdhi is necessary in order to prevent mind from becoming distracted in the second moment, then samÄdhi is useless with regard to the associated dharmas.
Moreover, it is on the basis of this samÄdhi that samÄdhi is accomplished.
Why does mind not concentrate on a single object on the basis of this mind itself?
Moreover, samÄdhi is a universal dharma and should cause all minds to concentrate on a single object.
This is not so, because in other classes of mind, samÄdhi is weak.
Other masters say:

When mind is in a state of concentration and continuity, this is called samÄdhi, because the scriptures say that it is the training in the higher mind, and because the most excellent purity of mind is the four meditations.
On the basis of what meaning is samÄdhi called meditation?
Because it is quiet and still and able to reflect and consider.

Reflection and consideration have the meaning of true knowledge, as when it is said that when the mind is in samÄdhi, it is able to know things as they really are. The meaning of reflection and consideration is to place the meaning of earth.
This school holds that reflection and consideration have wisdom as their substance.
In that case, all samÄdhis should be called meditation.
No, only the superior are given this name.
It is like the worldly saying that that which emits light is called the sun, and that fireflies and candles are not also called the sun.
How is meditation superior?

Only this meditation includes the members of the path, and the practice of calm and contemplation is most able to reflect and consider. It obtains the name of abiding in bliss in the present life and of the path of bliss. Therefore, this samÄdhi alone is called meditation.
If this is so, how can defiled states be called meditative development?
Because they also wrongly investigate. In that case, there would be the fault of over-extension.
There is no fault of over-extension, because the name is established only in a similar case, just as a bad seed, etc.
The World-Honored One also says that there is evil meditative concentration.
If one-pointedness of mind is the essence of meditative concentration, on what basis are the first, second, third, and fourth [meditative concentrations] established?

It is established as the first [meditative concentration] because it is endowed with applied thought, sustained thought, joy, and pleasure. By this, it is already clear that it also has initial thought, because they necessarily occur together, just as smoke and fire do.
It is not that there is joy and pleasure without being accompanied by initial thought.

The second, third, and fourth [meditative concentrations] are established by gradually abandoning the previous factors. There are two [meditative concentrations] that abandon applied thought, two that abandon sustained thought, and one that abandonly abandons all three.
One-pointedness of mind is divided into four kinds in this order.
Meditative concentration has already been discussed.
What about the formless [absorptions]?
The verse states:
The formless [absorptions] are also like this, with four aggregates abandoning the lower stages,
Together with the three proximate [absorptions], they are collectively called the elimination of the notion of form.
The formless [absorptions] are called formless because there is no form [in them]. The arising of form [in the formless realm] comes from the mind.
The three [absorptions] beginning with infinite space are named according to their preparatory practice.
The [absorption] of neither-perception-nor-non-perception is named because it is dull and inferior.
The treatise says:
The number of these [formless absorptions] is the same as the nature of the dhyÄnas, namely, each has two [types].
The birth [in the formless realm] is as explained above. The same treatise [i.e., the Compendium of the Great Vehicle] says that there are four [types of birth] due to birth.
The essence of the formless absorptions, in general, is also categorized as the wholesome nature of one-pointedness of mind.
Based on this, it says the same is true [for the formless absorptions].
However, in their accompanying factors, these [formless absorptions] exclude the form aggregate, because there is no form that accompanies [the formless absorptions].
Although the nature of one-pointedness of mind is without distinction in essence, it is divided into four types because [the formless absorptions] are separated from the birth in the lower stages.

That is to say, if one is separated from the birth in the fourth dhyÄna, one establishes the sphere of infinite space, and so on up to if one is separated from the birth in the sphere of nothingness, one establishes the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
What is the meaning of separation?
That is, the path by which one is liberated from the passions of a lower stage is the meaning of â€œfree from the passions of a lower stage.â€
These four fundamental and three proximate stages are all called â€œthe elimination of the notion of form.â€
The preliminary stage of the sphere of unlimited space is not yet given this name, because it generates the notion of form of a lower stage.
They are all called formless because they are formless, but this reason is not established, because they are admitted to have form.
If this is so, why are they called formless?
They are called formless because their form is subtle, just as a very yellow thing is called formless.
What are the characteristics of the form that is admitted in that realm?
If they only have the morality of body and speech,
how can there be morality if there is no body or speech?
Moreover, if there is no primary element, how can there be derivative form?
If you say that it is like pure morality,
this is not so, because pure morality is based on impure primary elements, and also because the existence of form is denied in those samÄdhis.
If you admit that there is a body with material organs in those states, how can you say that the form is subtle?
If you say that they are called formless because their bodies are small, then water animals and atoms should also be called formless, because their bodies are also small and invisible.
If you say that they are called formless because their bodies are extremely clear and subtle, then the form of the realm of form should be called formless.
If you say that they are called formless because their bodies are the most clear and subtle, then only the summit of existence should be called formless.

Because the bodies born in the formless realm are superior and inferior, and because the bodies born in the heavens of the meditations cannot be grasped by the organs of lower stages, how are they different from the formless realm and not called formless?
If you say that the names of the realms of desire and form are established according to their meanings, but not so for the formless,
what is the reason for this?

If you say that the scriptures say that life and heat are united, and that name-and-form and consciousness support each other like two bundles of reeds standing by mutual support, and that name-and-form have consciousness as a condition, and that consciousness comes and goes in dependence on name-and-form, and that consciousness comes and goes in dependence on name-and-form, and that consciousness comes and goes in dependence on form, etc., up to consciousness coming and going in dependence on conceptualization, and that therefore the formless realm has form,
this proof is not established, because it must be carefully considered.
That is, we should carefully consider the scriptures that are cited. The scriptures say that life and heat are united. Do they refer to all realms or only the desire realm?
Name-and-form and consciousness abide in mutual dependence. Do they refer to all realms or only the desire and form realms?

The scriptures say that name-and-form are conditioned by consciousness. Do they mean that all consciousness is a condition for name-and-form, or that there is no arising of name-and-form that is not conditioned by consciousness?

The scriptures say that consciousness comes and goes when separated from form, etc., up to and including volitions. Do they mean that it comes and goes when separated from any one of these, or that it comes and goes when separated from all of them?
If you say that the scriptures do not distinguish among them, then we should not think about this any further.
This explanation is not correct, because it is too broad.
That is, external heat should also be united with life.
Also, external name-and-form should depend on consciousness, and consciousness should be its condition.
Also, the four foods are like the four abodes of consciousness. The form and formless realms should have material food.

If you say that there is no error in this interpretation because a scripture says that there is a class of gods that transcends gross food and also says that the food of these gods is joy, then form does not exist in the formless realm, because a scripture says that one is freed from form.
Also, a scripture says,
The formless liberation is the most tranquil, because it transcends all form.
Also, a scripture says,
All formless sentient beings transcend all thoughts of form.
If form really exists in the formless realm, then its own characteristics should be knowable, so how can it be said that one transcends thoughts of form, etc.?
If you say that this is said because one contemplates the coarseness of lower form, then you must also accept this to be so of gross food.
Also, the meditative tranquility that transcends the coarseness of lower form should be said to be freed from form, and then it should be called the formless realm.
Also, one should say that it is freed from feelings, etc., because it also transcends the coarseness of lower feelings, etc.
Since the scriptures do not say that one transcends the class of form in the formless realms, one does not transcend feeling, etc.
Therefore we know with certainty that there is no form in those realms.

The scriptures say that one does not emerge from existence, because one is unable to transcend the existence of oneâ€™s own realm, because one does not transcend all realms, and because one does not transcend forever.

The Buddha, in the passages on the dhyÄnas, speaks of the class of form, etc., up to the class of consciousness. In the passages on the formless realms, he speaks of the class of feeling, etc., up to the class of consciousness, but not of the class of form.
If there really is form in the formless realms, why does he not speak of the class of form as he does in the passages on the dhyÄnas?
Therefore the reason given by the opponent is not established.
The continuity of form is interrupted for many kalpas in those realms. When one dies and is reborn in a lower realm, how does form arise again?
It arises from mind, not from form.
That is, the cause of the retribution of form that was produced in the past perfumes the mind, and its power is now mature. Therefore form now arises from that mind.
On what do the formless mind and body depend in order to continue?
Why does it not occur apart from the body?
Because it has never been seen below.
The realm of form is devoid of gross food. On what does the body there depend in order to continue?
Because it has never been seen that the body continues apart from gross food.

Also, it was said previously that the mind that evolves is the support. The general name has been explained. Do the specific names of the three, namely, Ä€kÄÅ›ÄnantyÄyatana, etc., come from taking space, etc., as objects?ğŸ”½No.
How then?
The lower three formless realms are named according to the object of contemplation in the path of added effort, namely, infinite space, infinite consciousness, and nothingness.

The fourth is named according to the weakness of conceptualization, i.e., the absence of superior conceptualization is called non-conceptualization, and the presence of weak conceptualization is called neither conceptualization nor non-conceptualization.
Even though in the path of added effort one also thinks,
Conceptualization is like a disease, like an arrow, like a boil.

If conceptualization is totally absent, one is the same as a block of wood or stone. Only in the state of neither conceptualization nor non-conceptualization is there a state that is contrary to the above, namely, tranquil and wonderful. However, this is not the name given to the path of added effort.
If one asks why the preparatory stage is called this,
one must answer that it is because the conceptualization in that realm is weak.
Because of this weakness, it is the correct reason for the name.
The formless realms have been explained.
What are the meditative attainments?
A verse says:
These fundamental meditative attainments are eight. The first seven each have three.
They are called enjoyment, pure, and uncontaminated. The last two are enjoyment and pure.
Enjoyment means associated with craving. Pure means worldly good.
This is what is enjoyed. Uncontaminated means supramundane.
The treatise says:

The fundamental meditative attainments explained above are eight. Among them, the first seven each have three kinds. The meditative attainment of the peak of existence only has two kinds, because this realm is dull and inferior and lacks the uncontaminated.

The first enjoyment meditative attainment means that which is associated with craving. Because craving can enjoy and savor, it is called enjoyment. Because it is associated with that, it is called enjoyment.
The name â€œpure meditative absorptionâ€ refers to the good worldly meditative absorptions, because they are born in association with such pure good dharmas as noncraving.

The object of enjoyment of the defiled meditative absorption is the object of enjoyment of the pure meditative absorption. The pure meditative absorption is born immediately after the extinction of the object of enjoyment.

One deeply enjoys the past pure meditative absorption, and at that time, although one is said to emerge from the meditative absorption of enjoyment, one is said to enter the meditative absorption of enjoyment.
The pure meditative absorption is the supramundane meditative absorption, because it is not the object of craving and is not enjoyed.
The eight meditative absorptions mentioned above include the members of the four meditations, but not those of the formless realms.
How many members are there in the four meditations?
A verse says:
The first meditation has five members: investigation, sustained thought, joy, happiness, and unification of mind.
The second has four members: internal purity, joy, happiness, and unification of mind.
The third has five members: equanimity, mindfulness, wisdom, happiness, and unification of mind.
The fourth has four members: pure equanimity, pure mindfulness, neither happiness nor suffering, and unification of mind.
A treatise says:
The first of the four pure and uncontaminated dhyÄnas is endowed with five members:
1. initial thought, 2. sustained thought, 3. joy, 4. pleasure, and 5. samÄdhi.
This samÄdhi is called dhyÄna in the verse, and samÄdhi and dhyÄna are synonymous. Therefore a scripture says, â€œMind in samÄdhi and samÄdhi are called right samÄdhi.â€
This is also called one-pointedness of mind, the meaning of which has been explained above.
It is said that only samÄdhi is dhyÄna and also a member of dhyÄna, while the other four members are members of dhyÄna but not dhyÄna.
According to the correct interpretation, it is like an army with four members. The other members of dhyÄna should be understood in the same way.
The second dhyÄna has only four members:
1. internal purity, 2. joy, 3. pleasure, and 4. samÄdhi.
The third dhyÄna has all five members:
1. equanimity, 2. right mindfulness, 3. right knowledge, 4. the feeling of pleasure, and 5. samÄdhi.
The fourth dhyÄna has only four members:
The first is the purity of equanimity, the second is the purity of mindfulness, the third is the feeling of neither suffering nor joy, and the fourth is samÄdhi.
Since the names of the factors of dhyÄna are eighteen, how many real entities are there in total?
Verse:
There are eleven real entities. The first two are joy and pliancy.
Inner purity is the faculty of faith, and joy is the feeling of joy.
Treatise:
There are only eleven real entities for these factors. The first five factors are five real entities.
The second dhyÄna has three factors as before, and adding the factor of inner purity makes six.
The third dhyÄna has samÄdhi as before, and adding the remaining four factors makes ten.
The fourth dhyÄna has three factors as before, and adding the factor of neither suffering nor joy makes eleven.
For this reason, it is said that there are factors of the first dhyÄna that are not factors of the second dhyÄna. Four sentences should be made.
The first sentence is initial and sustained thought.
The second sentence is inner purity.
The third line refers to joy, pleasure, and samÄdhi.
The fourth line.
Refers to dharmas other than the above.
The remaining members should be considered in the same way.
Why is it said in the third [meditation] that pleasure increases?
Because in the first two [meditations] pleasure is included in serenity.
What principle is there to prove that it is serenity?
Because in the first two meditations there is no faculty of pleasure.
There is no bodily pleasure in the first two meditations, because while one is in samÄdhi there are no five sense consciousnesses.
Nor is there mental pleasure, because it is said that there is joy.
Joy is the feeling of joy, and two feelings do not occur together in a single moment of mind, and therefore there is no feeling of pleasure.
It is impossible for pleasure and joy to appear alternately, because it is said that the third meditation has five members and the second has four.
Some say:
There is no mental feeling of the faculty of pleasure. The member of pleasure in the three meditations is all categorized as the faculty of pleasure that is bodily feeling.
If this is so, why does a scripture say:
What is the faculty of pleasure?
That is, it is bodily and mental pleasure born from the power of the contact that accords with pleasure.
Some add the word â€œmindâ€ here, but the scriptures of various schools only speak of the body.
Also, the third concentration is established as having the factor of pleasure, because the scriptures themselves say that it is pleasure experienced by the body.
If it is said that in this context mind is referred to as body, what is the merit of this designation of body?
Also, in the fourth concentration, lightness increases even more, but it is not said that it has the factor of pleasure.

If it is said that lightness must accord with the feeling of pleasure in order to be called pleasure, then the lightness of the third concentration should accord with pleasure and be a factor of pleasure.
If it is said that that lightness is damaged by the equanimity of the third concentration,
that is not so, because the equanimity of the third concentration increases lightness.
Also, because that lightness is superior to that of the first two concentrations.
Also, a scripture says:

When the noble disciples realize and dwell in the joy and pleasure born of separation, at that time they have already eliminated five dharmas and cultivated five dharmas to perfection, and so on. What are the five dharmas cultivated?
One is joy, two is pleasure, three is pliancy, four is happiness, five is samÄdhi.
Since this sÅ«tra separately mentions pliancy and pleasure, the first two kinds of pleasure are not identical with pliancy.
If it is said that how can there be bodily consciousness in samÄdhi?

Even if there is, there is no error. It is allowed that in samÄdhi there is a wind of pliancy produced by the excellent samÄdhi, which universally touches the body in accordance with the production of the feeling of pleasure.

If it is said that because it scatters externally it should destroy samÄdhi, there is no such error. This wind of pliancy is born from the excellent samÄdhi, and it can still accord with the production of samÄdhi by drawing in the pleasure of the internal body.
If it is said that the production of bodily consciousness should be called emerging from samÄdhi, this objection is not correct, for the previous reason.

If you say that the body faculty of the realm of desire cannot produce a tactile consciousness of the realm of form, we reply that there is no error in admitting that the tactile consciousness that has pliancy as its object can be produced.
If this is so, then tactile consciousness and the body faculty must be pure when one is in a state of pure meditation.
We reply that you must not say that some of the members of the state of meditation are pure and some are impure, because this contradicts reason.
We reply that there is no such error.
Why is this?
Because we admit that pliancy of the body is included among the members of the state of meditation.
If you say that it is called a member of the state of meditation because it is favorable to it, then we reply that it must be admitted that the pure state is also so called.
If you admit that it is so called, then you contradict the scriptures.
A scripture says,
All that is eye, etc.

This scripture says that the fifteen elements are all impure, and therefore there is no contradiction with the scriptures, because this passage refers to other tactile consciousnesses and other body faculties in an implicit way.
How can it be that when a pure meditation is present, some members are pure and some are impure?
What error is involved in their not arising simultaneously?
If you say that joy and pleasure do not occur together, then there should be no five members and four members.
This is also not a fault, because it is said that they exist when they are possible, just as there is applied thought and sustained thought.
If you say that applied thought and sustained thought also occur together, then they cannot be used as examples for that which does not occur together.
This is not a failure, because the grossness and subtlety of mind are mutually contradictory and should not occur together.
Also, because it cannot be said that they do not occur together.

Therefore it can be said that the second and following meditative states are established by reducing two, three, and four members from the first, which has five members. For this reason, the first is said to have five members, because it is intended to gradually eliminate the former and establish the latter.
Because there is no gradual reduction, it is not said that ideation, etc., are members.
Or it should be said, why are only five members established in the first?
If you say that these five are superior in nourishing the first meditative state, therefore they are established as members.
This is unreasonable, because mindfulness and wisdom are superior in nourishing it, more than applied thought and sustained thought.
Although there is one opinion that this is so, still it is not the opinion of the ancient masters, and therefore we must examine it.
What is the dharma called internal purity?
This samÄdhi is far removed from the agitation of applied and sustained thought, and its continuity is pure and evolves as internal purity.
If there is agitation by applied and sustained thought, the continuity is not pure and evolves like a river with waves.
In that case, it must not have a separate substance. How can it be admitted that there are eleven real entities?
Therefore we must say that it is the faculty of faith.

If one realizes the second trance state, then one produces a deep faith in the ability to be free from the agitation of applied and sustained thought in the stage of concentration, and this is called internal purity.
Faith has purity as its characteristic, and therefore it is called purity.
It is called internal because it is free from external agitation.
It is called internal purity because it is pure and internally equal.
Other masters say:
Internal purity, samÄdhi, applied thought, and sustained thought all have no separate substance.
If there is no separate substance, mental activities would not exist, but a difference in the state of mind is also called a mental activity.
Although this is reasonable, it is not the opinion of our school.
As stated above, joy is the feeling of joy.
What is the evidence that this is definitely so?
Do you say that joy is not the feeling of joy, as other schools admit? We also admit this.
How do other schools admit that it is not the feeling of joy?
They say that there is a separate mental activity called joy, and the pleasure of the three trance states is all the feeling of joy. Therefore, joy and the feeling of joy are different in substance.
The pleasure of the three trance states cannot be called the feeling of joy, because it is clearly proven by two scriptures.
The Scripture on the Elimination of Errors says,

The five faculties such as sorrow are gradually and completely eliminated, and in the third trance state, joy is completely eliminated, and in the fourth trance state, pleasure is completely eliminated.
Also, another scripture says,
In the fourth trance state, one eliminates pleasure, eliminates pain, and previously eliminated sorrow and joy.
Therefore the third trance definitely does not have the faculty of delight. Consequently, this feeling of delight is delight and not pleasure.
Are all the members of the trances as explained above found in defiled samÄdhi?
No, it is not so.ğŸ”½
How is it?
A verse says:
In defiled samÄdhi, from the first there is no joy, pleasure, or internal purity.
Right mindfulness, wisdom, equanimity, and mindfulness are missing, and others say there is no serenity or equanimity.
The treatise says:
The members of the trances as explained above are not all found in defiled samÄdhi.
First, there is one opinion that says:
In the first defiled trance, there is no separation from birth, joy, and pleasure, because it is not born from separation from the passions.
In the second defiled trance, there is no internal purity, because it is disturbed by the passions.
In the third defiled trance, there is no right mindfulness and wisdom, because one is confused by defiled pleasure.
In the fourth defiled trance, there is no purity of equanimity and mindfulness, because it is defiled by the passions.
Other masters say:
The first two defiled concentrations lack only serenity, and the last two defiled concentrations lack only equanimity, because they are included in the great ground of wholesomeness.
A scripture says,
The first three concentrations have movement, but the fourth is without movement.
On the basis of what is this said?
A verse says,
The fourth is called immovable, because it is free of the eight faults.
The eight are initial and sustained thought, four feelings, and inhalation and exhalation.
The treatise says,
The lower three concentrations are called with movement because they have faults.
The fourth concentration is called without movement because it is free of faults.
There are eight faults. What are the eight?
Initial thought, sustained thought, four feelings, inhalation, and exhalation.
The fourth concentration is completely free of these eight faults, and for that reason the World Honored One said it is without movement.
However, a scripture says,
The fourth concentration is not moved by initial thought, sustained thought, joy, pleasure, or the mind.
Other masters say,
The fourth concentration is like a lamp in a closed room that is still and unmoved.
Are the feelings that arise in the various meditations the same as those in the meditations?
No, they are not.
How are they?
In verse it is said:
In the meditations of birth, from the first there are feelings of joy, pleasure, and equanimity,
Joy and equanimity, pleasure and equanimity, and only equanimity, in order.
In the treatise it is said:
In the meditations of birth, the first has three feelings:
One is the feeling of joy, associated with mental consciousness;
Two is the feeling of pleasure, associated with three consciousnesses;
Three is the feeling of equanimity, associated with four consciousnesses.
The second has two, namely joy and equanimity, associated with mental consciousness. There is no feeling of pleasure, because there are no other consciousnesses, and because mental joy is coarse.
The third has two, namely pleasure and equanimity, associated with mental consciousness.
The fourth has one, namely only the feeling of equanimity, associated with mental consciousness.
These are called the differences in feelings arising from the meditations.
In the upper three meditations there are no three kinds of consciousnesses, and no initial and sustained thought. How can one who is born there see, hear, touch, and give rise to expressive actions?
It is not that eye consciousness and so on do not exist in those realms, but they are not bound to those realms.
Why is this?
Verse:
When born in the upper three meditations, the three consciousnesses, revealing minds,
Are all included in the first meditation, only being undefiled and indeterminate.
The Treatise says:
When born in the upper three stages, the three consciousnesses and revealing minds are all bound to the first meditation.
Because when born in the upper stages, they are like the mind of transformation, therefore they can see, hear, touch, and reveal. These four are only undefiled and indeterminate.
They do not give rise to the defiled [minds of the lower stages], because they have already been separated from the defiled [minds of the lower stages].
They do not give rise to the good [minds of the lower stages], because [the good minds of the lower stages] are inferior.
Thus the specific explanation of the meditations is completed.
How does one initially attain the pure and so on meditative attainments?
Verse:
One does not completely attain the pure [meditations] by separation from defilements or birth,
The uncontaminated [meditations] by separation from defilements, the defiled [meditations] by birth and regression.
The Treatise says:

The eight fundamental meditative attainments, as appropriate, if one does not completely accomplish them and obtains them, the pure [attainments] are due to separation from defilements and due to rebirth. This means that in the lower stages, one is separated from the defilements of the lower stages, and when one is reborn in the upper stages, one is in one's own stage.
The seven lower [stages] are all like this.
The peak of existence is not like this. It is only due to separation from defilements, not due to rebirth.
Why is it said that if one does not completely accomplish [the fundamental meditative attainments], one obtains them?

This is to exclude the case where one who has already accomplished [the fundamental meditative attainments] obtains a small part, such as the factors conducive to penetration through applied practice, and the attainment of the factors conducive to regression through regression.
Based on this meaning, it is asked:
Is there any pure meditative attainment that is obtained through separation from defilements?
Separation from defilements and abandonment through regression and birth are also asked about in the same way.
[The answer is:]
There is. Namely, the factors conducive to regression.

First, the factors conducive to regression in the first meditative absorption are obtained when one is separated from the defilements of the desire realm, abandoned when one is separated from one's own [defilements], obtained when one regresses and is separated from one's own [defilements], and abandoned when one regresses and is separated from the defilements of the desire realm.
From the higher to the lower, one obtains through birth and through cultivation. From the lower to the higher, one obtains only through cultivation.
The other stages should be considered in the same way.
The pure [attainments] are obtained only through detachment, that is, when the noble ones detach from the lower stages, they obtain the pure [attainments] of the higher stages.

This is also based on those who have not fully accomplished [the higher stages]. If one has already accomplished [the higher stages], one can also obtain them at other times.
